abstract.0:
The AdoptOpenJDK Build Farm is a new community project producing high-quality OpenJDK binaries for all versions, platforms, and variants. Want Java 10 with OpenJ9 on AIX or maybe Java 8 with HotSpot on macOS? AdoptOpenJDK can help! This session covers how 200+ people (from companies such as IBM, Oracle, and Red Hat), cloud providers, and the wider Java community (e.g., the LJC) collaborated to create a full build farm in under a year for the common good. Also learn how a modern CI build+test pipeline works:
• Building hosts with Ansible
• Build coordination with Jenkins
• Advanced shell scripts for building Java on any platform
• Swaths of testing
• Certification
•Deploying binaries via AdoptOpenJDK.net and the API gateway
abstract.1: Angular is one of the leading JavaScript frameworks for front-end development, and it is been largely adopted by the enterprise. Because Angular uses TypeScript, a JavaScript superset, developers are able to leverage their Java knowledge to learn Angular quickly. In this session, you will learn some tips and tricks to make the Angular learning curve easier and also how some Java patterns can be leveraged in Angular to help developers design and code Angular applications for the enterprise. At the end of the tutorial, you will learn different approaches to deploying the applications in the cloud.
abstract.2: Mobile applications are becoming increasingly important for businesses. This session describes how you can leverage your Java and JavaFX skills to create mobile applications and deploy them on iOS as well as Android platforms. With a plug-in from Gluon and your favorite IDE, you have a framework that gives you write once, run anywhere technology and a way to communicate with cloud data securely. The presentation also shows you how to decouple client-side code from the back-end implementation, such as Oracle Cloud, and why this is advantageous.
abstract.3: The blockchain is an undeniably ingenious invention. Ethereum is an open source programmable platform that enables anyone to build a blockchain, create their own operations, and use decentralized apps running on blockchain technology. The public blockchain is open to anyone who wants to deploy smart contracts and have their executions performed by public mining nodes. This session highlights the Ethereum Blockchain fundamental and the steps to get a private blockchain up and running. At the end of this session, you should be able to set up two or more running nodes on one local machine, build your first smart contract, send transactions between nodes, mine them, and finally verify the results by making sure that all nodes have the same copies.
abstract.4: This deep-dive session takes you into the magical world of GraphQL, which offers a “new” way of building cool and responsive APIs. It shows and explains to you what GraphQL is, how we can build GraphQL APIs in good old Java, when and why you should use GraphQL, and also when and where not to use it. Come seeking knowledge, and you will leave the session with new tricks in your bag and great knowledge of GraphQL.
abstract.5:
Java is moving faster and faster, and a lot of features are not as well known as they should be. This tutorial reviews the ones you’re likely to have missed in old versions.

Then I will kickstart you on 9, 10 and 11 features that you never had time to look at.
abstract.6: You’re a Java developer? Already familiar with Docker? Want to know more about Kubernetes and its ecosystem for developers? During this session, you’ll get familiar with core Kubernetes concepts (pods, deployments, services, volumes, and so on) before seeing the most-popular and most-productive Kubernetes tools in action, with a special focus on Java development. By the end of the session, you’ll have a better understanding of how you can leverage Kubernetes to speed up your Java deployments on-premises or to any cloud.
abstract.7: Java 9 introduced JShell as a REPL tool, and var arrived with Java 10. They make it easy to learn Java. In this session, you’ll start to learn Java 11 with JShell from the beginning.
abstract.8: During this tutorial, you will learn how to use MySQL 8.0 Document Store and how you will able to mix NoSQL and SQL. Come to discover this new MySQL feature and see all the possibilities it offers you. You’ll be surprised!
abstract.9: Are you tired of null pointer exceptions, unintended side effects, SQL injections, concurrency errors, mistaken equality tests, and other runtime errors? Are your users tired of them in your code? In this tutorial, you will learn how to guarantee, at compile time, that these runtime exceptions cannot occur; you will learn the concepts of (pluggable) type checking; you will use existing type systems; you will learn to write your own type system that checks consistent use of encryption; and you will see a presentation on the design and usage of more-advanced checkers. The tool is in use at companies such as Amazon, Google, and Uber and is freely available at http://checkerframework.org/. You have nothing to lose but your bugs!
abstract.10: Apache Kafka is a key component in enterprise data architecture today. Kafka manages streaming data sources such as IoT device feeds, clickstream data, and social media feeds. For applications that need to query streaming data and react in real time, Oracle SQL access to Kafka Streams gives SQL developers a simple and powerful way to query Kafka Streams and integrate streaming data with database data. This session walks through use cases involving Oracle Cloud services and shows step-by-step how to use Oracle SQL to query Kafka Streams, join Kafka Streams with database tables, and load high-speed streaming data into the database.
abstract.11: Joshua Bloch just gifted us with the third edition of Effective Java, but almost 10 years have passed since the last edition. Now we have a whole generation of Java developers that could benefit from this knowledge. It’s about time to revisit all this wonderful content and upgrade your skills to the latest versions of the Java platform. Attend this deep-dive session to check out the updated Effective Java and even get some more tips not included in the book.
abstract.12: This session discusses asynchronous, nonblocking remote services invocations with the Fn project, an open source, container-native, polyglot, serverless platform. It zooms in to one of Fn’s killer features, Fn Flow, an API that enables you to simply and asynchronously compose functions in a distributed but type-safe way. The presentation first introduces Fn Flow and its inner workings. It then contrasts and compares Flow with some standard APIs, such as CompletableFuture and JAX-RS, that can be used to compose similar services chaining. The presenters then use Fn Flow to develop a real workflow that composes multiple functions. The session concludes with a discussion of how key aspects such as error handling and resilience can be handled in a simple and intuitive way.
abstract.13: This session walks through all the steps of building a modern, distributed application based on the Java Platform Module System, introduced in Java 9. Modules are easy to understand in concept, but getting started with using them in a real project might be more daunting. How do we use it with real (build) tools, libraries, and application requirements? This code-driven presentation sets up a Gradle build, structures the application in modules, and uses Vert.x to add web functionality to the application. Along the way, you will learn about services, which are an important tool for decoupling modules; modularity patterns and best practices; and ways to test modules.
abstract.14:
The Binary Log is primarily used as a logical replication log for
MySQL. However, ever since row-based replication was introduced it has
also been widely used as an integration point between a MySQL server
and other components in an IT infrastructure. It is often used as a
capture-data-changes stream, as a source of data for
extract-transform-load operations or even as an event notification
trigger.Commonly deployed setups revolve around collecting/subscribing to data
changes and propagating these to downstream consumers through a
message bus, like Kafka for instance. This session will present such use cases, highlighting the additional
metadata added to the binary log in the latest releases and more...

10.value: Database, Big Data, and Data Science

0.bio: Daniel Bryant works as an Independent Technical Consultant, and currently specialises in enabling continuous delivery within organisations through the identification of value streams, creation of build pipelines, and implementation of effective testing strategies. Daniel’s technical expertise focuses on ‘DevOps’ tooling, cloud/container platforms, and microservice implementations. He also contributes to several open source projects, writes for InfoQ, O’Reilly, and Voxxed, and regularly presents at international conferences such as OSCON, QCon and JavaOne.
0.globalBio: Daniel Bryant works as an Independent Technical Consultant, and currently specialises in enabling continuous delivery within organisations through the identification of value streams, creation of build pipelines, and implementation of effective testing strategies. Daniel’s technical expertise focuses on ‘DevOps’ tooling, cloud/container platforms, and microservice implementations. He also contributes to several open source projects, writes for InfoQ, O’Reilly, and Voxxed, and regularly presents at international conferences such as OSCON, QCon and JavaOne.

2.bio: Paul L. Anderson is an Oracle Developer Champion, Java Champion, and a member of the NetBeans Dream Team. He is the Director of Training and founding member of the Anderson Software Group, a leading provider of training courses in Java, JavaFX, Python, Go, Modern C++, and other programming languages.  Paul is an experienced speaker and specializes in making the technical aspects of software engineering fun and understandable. He is the co-author of eight textbooks on software programming, including JavaFX Rich Client Programming on the NetBeans Platform.  Paul has conducted Technical Sessions and Hands-on Labs at JavaOne and NetBeans Day conferences in San Francisco, Europe, and Latin America.  Paul has also presented sessions at Devoxx and DevNexus and is the author of LiveLesson videos on JavaFX Programming and Java Reflection.   For more information about Paul, visit asgteach.com, the Anderson Software Group on Facebook, and @paul_asgteach on Twitter.

9.bio: Werner Dietl is an assistant professor in Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Waterloo, Canada. His research interests are in safe and productive software development. He combines theoretical results with practical tools so developers can create high-quality, trustworthy software and reduce the enormous impact of software defects.

9.bio:
Michael Ernst loves programming. and he loves programmers.  He wants to make their lives better by building programming tools.  A notable example is the Checker Framework, which strengthens Java's type system in order to prevent more bugs.  He was also the specification lead for JSR-308, which extended Java's annotation syntax and won a Most Innovative JSR award.

As a professor at the University of Washington, his research aims to make software more reliable, more secure, and easier (and more fun!) to produce.  Ernst's research combines strong theoretical foundations with realistic experimentation, with an eye to changing the way that software developers work.
He publishes in software engineering, programming languages, type theory, security, program analysis, bug prediction, testing, and verification. 

Dr. Ernst was previously a developer at Microsoft, a researcher at Microsoft Research, and a tenured professor at MIT.
9.globalBio:
Michael Ernst loves programming. and he loves programmers.  He wants to make their lives better by building programming tools. 10.bio:
Melli Annamalai is a product manager at Oracle.  She has vast experience in multiple technology areas related to
unstructured and semi-structured data management. One of her current focus areas is Big Data, with an emphasis 
on integrating data from streaming sources and Hadoop environments with Oracle Database.  
She works closely with customers as they deploy solutions using Oracle Big Data products. 
She is a regular presenter at Oracle Open World and other industry events.
10.globalBio: Melli Annamalai is a product manager at Oracle.  She has 20+ years experience in extending the database to  work with unstructed and semi-structured data, including multimedia data, data in Apache Hadoop platforms,  property graphs, and RDF knowledge graphs.  One of her current focus areas is enabling the database to  work with streaming data. As part of her role she works closely with customers as they develop and deploy  solutions to solve their business problems, gaining insights to guide development of features and  functionality in a product.  She is a regular presenter at Oracle Open World, Oracle User Group meetings,  and other industry events.  Melli has a Ph.D. in Computer Science From Purdue University.

11.bio:
Edson Yanaga, Red Hat's Director of Developer Experience, is a Java Champion and a Microsoft MVP. He is also a published author and a frequent speaker at international conferences, discussing Java, Microservices, Cloud Computing, DevOps, and Software Craftsmanship. 

Yanaga considers himself a software craftsman, and is convinced that we all can create a better world for people with better software. His life's purpose is to deliver and help developers worldwide to deliver better software faster and safely - and he can even call that a job!

12.bio:
José is an assistant professor at the Institut Galilée (Université Paris 13) and a PhD in applied mathematics from the ENS de Cachan. He has discovered the Java language in 1995, and has been teaching the Java technologies at the university since 1998. José is also a Java Champion and Java Rockstar. 
 
José has also been working as an independant for numerous companies, in a variety of areas. He is a well known Java / Java EE / Software Craftsmanship expert and trainer. You can find him on GitHub (https://github.com/JosePaumard), Slideshare (https://www.slideshare.net/jpaumard), YouTube (https://www.youtube.com/user/JPaumard) and Pluralsight (https://app.pluralsight.com/profile/author/jose-paumard).

David works in the Project Fn/Serverless Developer Relations Team at Oracle. Prior to that, he was involved in Java EE 8 and its transition to the Eclipse Foundation as part of the Jakarta EE initiative. Over the years, David has championed Java extensively throughout the world, presenting at conferences and user groups, large and small.

14.bio: Luís Soares is the MySQL Replication Software Development Director at Oracle. His research interests include replication technologies, dependable systems and high availability. Before joining the MySQL team, he was both a post-graduate student and a researcher at the University of Minho, Portugal, where he designed and implemented group-based replication protocols. Before that, he worked for a Portuguese multi-national company as a system analyst.
